This mount connects your RaspberryPi Camera to your 1.25 inch eyepiece focuser of your telescope. Needs the RaspberryPiCamera.scad: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:123218 Remove the lens if you want to see stars
Leave the lens on if you want to use the camera for collimation of your telescope You can try to mount it on top of this housing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:89745 Update: The printed parts fit! I uploaded some pictures to give you a better impression. Changelog: V2: The lower M2 screws hit the cylinder. I opened the cylinder, in order to fit a regurla DIN 912 M2 screw. The inner ractangle was enlarged, to avoid problems with the front cable.

author: B3buggy

title: CTC PROBLEM PLEASE HELP I TRYED EVERYTHING

description.text: Hi guys, I recently purchased a CTC 3D printer, I was able to print a couple of things then the extruder started to click. I was printing with PLA on the right extruder and I switched over to the left extruder, but then that one started to click as well. When the motor clicks the plastic doesn't come out. Even if I push really hard with the plastic on the top, it still wont stop clicking. I put some vegetable oil in the extuder and that seemed to help but one for a short while. Is there a fix? I also tried different temps but nothing worked. I also cant figure out how to remove the nozzle, it seems like its too tight, and i don't want to break anything. I really want to fix this problem so if anyone can help that would be great. Thanks.

comments.text: I have had a the same problem with my CTC printer worked fine when new out the box and using PLA filament supplied, but I knew from what I had read that in time the extruders would become a problem. Straight out the box I placed an order for " Printer MK8 Aluminium Alloy Extruder Frame Blocks" both left and right new nozzle barrels and mounting plate block also replaced the heat sinks to match the gold look. before the parts arrived the bearing in the shipped extruder had fell apart so I swapped them from left to right in time the extruder was slipping on some types of filament I had 12 kilo of filaments both ABS and PLA and some where harder to feed than others.  By the time the parts arrived which took some 30 days I had used the printer almost non stop so needed the upgrade. The parts arrived and I fitted them found the best way to set both nozzle heights is to use a paper shim under the low nozzle side to set it to the printer bed which in my case I had converted to using glass. the spring loaded extruders work really good now but you have to watch the stepper motor cooling if they get to warm they do tend to stop working. I use a fan across the top of the printer avoiding the nozzles. I also fitted a active fan around the nozzles. I have so far printed all sorts of filaments and have found that glue sticks work fine on glass for PLA and masking tape and PVA glue for ABS items depends on if your using rafts or the size of the item I have also found that on really flat surfaces its best to have gaps to help stop warping. I am still learning and make no claim that I know what I am doing. I am only posting my suggestions.
comments.author: Camville14

comments.text: If you have not resolved this problem you need to loosen the two screws on top and tighten screw on fan. If they are not loose you need to disassemble and resituate the pieces. Tighten fan screws that go to stepper motor first. Then top long screws.

comments.text: On this printer type we don't have a full metal hotend aka extruder so between the nozzle and extruder drive there is a metal tube that is hot so the filament melts ... To dispures the heat the added a ptfe or Teflon guide tube in there as insulation so the filament would only melt at the bottom near the nozzle so I am assuming you did the same thing I did abs runs about 230ish Celsius so you got a clog or warping/delaminates with your prints so like normal you crank the heats up because that's what a lot of people comment to do this actually prolly melted the tube inside and now is causing you jams during prolly the 20-30 min mark I tried everything in the book and this was the issue with mine
comments.author: Inteous

comments.text: Yes the Teflon tube will come out the top of the threaded tube if it gets pressure under it, and jam into the feed wheels, and then stops feeding and you hear the clicking of the feed wheel jumping over the filament. I welded a 3mm stainless washer to the top of a 6mm nut and screwed that to the TOP of the threaded tube where it sticks out above the heat sink block, just below the feed wheels. This stops the Teflon liner from coming up, and I have not had a single problem since. You could silver solder the washer on the nut, I TIG welded it.

comments.text: I'm by no means an expert, and I have zero familiarity with the CTC printers (I have a Printrbot Simple Maker Model 1405 [the wooden version]).  I was having what I thought was "clogged hot end" as the extruder would start "clicking" and not feeding filament through.  I finally tracked down the "root cause" to be that I didn't have enough tension on the idler wheel that holds the filament against the drive wheel.  You'll probably have to have the hot end and working temperature, then extract the filament.  Carefully clean the extruder (it has likely ground off some of the filament when it was clicking) of any dust (I like to dampen a cotton swab with rubbing alcohol and use that to clean off the entire wheel in the extruder).  Cut off two or three inches of the filament (be sure to make the cut at an angle), and after tightening up the tension adjustment screw a turn or two, heat up the hot end again and feed the filament in.

comments.text: The hotends have three basic parts: The throat which has a PTFE tube lining it, the heater block, and the nozzle. There is an aluminum block that the throat is anchored to by a grub screw and is what the motor & fan attach to. Depending on the nozzle you can use a 7.5 to 8 mm socket to unscrew it. If you just want to remove the nozzle use some pliers to hold the heater block while unscrewing it.

comments.text: Hi, I also own a CTC and can honestly say it doesn't like PLA printing much. The stock wire feeder extruders are awful, I quickly moved to one of the other designs posted here. Any switching between PLA and ABS can be troublesome and will often jam your hotend. I'd stay away from the CoolCube throats on eBay. The PTFE tube has a tendency to come out the top from the back pressure of the melting plastic. If you have one of the small wire brushes their bristles can be used to clear a block in the nozzle. You can also try using a dental pick. I used to use the drill bits, but they're easy to break off inside the nozzle. The condition of the PTFE tube itself can be a huge part of printing PLA well on the CTC. The best PLA printing I did was right after replacement of the throat the first time. Hope this helps.
comments.author: Pierrimus

This is a replica of the Thunderbird 3. Reference material came from ~Librarian-bot. (found here: http://librarian-bot.deviantart.com) Excerpt from wikipedia: A reusable, vertically launched SSTO (Single Stage To Orbit) spaceship used for space rescue and maintenance of Thunderbird 5. Thunderbird 3 is 87 m (287 feet) long, with a 7 m wide body and a 24 m span (including engines). Thunderbird 3 is unique among the Thunderbird craft in having its dimensions quoted in an episode of the series: in "Give or Take a Million" Jeff Tracy states that the spacecraft stands 287 feet (87m) high. However, Brains, the designer of Thunderbird 3, said in a videotaped interview,[4] that Thunderbird 3 was "200 feet in height. " Another problem with the stated size is evident in the Thunderbird 3 launch scenes. For the craft to be over 200 feet, the ceiling of the roundhouse it passes through on take-off would need to be in excess of 50 feet high and the balcony rail 25 feet high. http://airandspace.si.edu/exhibitions/gal114/SpaceRace/sec300/sec384.htm states that the Saturn V is 111m or 363 feet high at launch, adding validity to the 200 foot height theory.
The spacecraft uses chemical rockets for lift-off[disambiguation needed] and boost, and an ion drive for propulsion while in space. Thunderbird 3 is hangared beneath the "Round House" on Tracy Island, and is primarily piloted by Alan or John Tracy, although Scott often co-pilots. Since John is usually seen in Thunderbird 5, he is rarely seen piloting the spacecraft (only in "The Mighty Atom" and "Danger at Ocean Deep" and "The Uninvited", and never in a rescue situation). In "Ricochet" Virgil is seen piloting Thunderbird 3. This craft was used for space rescues in "Sun Probe", "Ricochet", "The Impostors" as well as escorting Zero X briefly in Thunderbirds Are Go.

Print the Thunderbird 3 in multiple parts, scale them to fit your printer, the largest part is 'driepoot v3.stl'. This item is also the most difficult to print, if you fail to print the small pillars in this file, try to print them individually (pilaartje.stl) and glue them to the main part. They are very thin, print slow, at a low temperature. You will probably need to trim the nose a bit as it is very pointy. Use glue to stick everything together! Take a picture, we would love to see another thunderbird! http://youtu.be/nFb4IVLXDss

description.text:
Onshape gear designer.
The linked Onshape document allows you to quickly generate gears in onshape ready to be exported as an STL and printed.

How to use the gear designer The onshape gear designer uses OnShape variables to allow you to define the properties of the required gear.
Simply update the required variables and your gear will be generated ready to be exported as an STL file and printed. *Variables
The following variables can be modified. #M - the gears modulus
#PD
#GearThickness - controls the thickness of the gear in millimetres. The remaining variables are calculated from the above three variables.
#NumTeeth - the number of teeth on the gear.
#RD
#OD - Outside Diameter of the gear.
#ToothWidth
#ToothFillet

The bushing is designed to be printed around a 6301z bearing. You are required
to pause the print before your printer begins working on the lip that will
seal in the bearing. This can be done by inserting two lines of code right
after the command to raise the Z axis like so:
G1 X0 Y0 ; move print to a more approachable position
M226 ; Gcode initiated Pause or Wait for pin state in Marlin
If your printer is a Marlin or the firmware is setup as one the M226
command should be omitted in favor of:
G1 X100 F50 ; move the printhead to X100 at 50mm/min
This will give you two minutes to insert the bearing into the cavity. The "leaves" create an intereference fit which can be adjusted by
changing the parameters in the SolidWorks Part file, In here it is also
possible to change the tolerances of the bearing, diameter of the rod and the
resting lip.

Printer:

Ormerod 2 528.4

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20% honeycomb

Notes: Filament: Verbatim white PLA 1.75mm
Hotend temperature: 195°C
Heated bed temperature: 55°C REMEMBER REMEMBER REMEMBER REMEMBER REMEMBER REMEMBER REMEMBER
Place the ball bearing on the heated bed so it comes up to temperature prior to inserting it. If the bearing is cold the extruded filament will curl up.

After the print is completed insert the bushing into a vise so the inner part cannot move. This helps you in drilling it out to fit whatever size rod you intend to insert. The .STL file is built to support a ~8mm rod.
When done the bushing can be removed from the vise and inserted into the desired roll of filament. The leafs are intended to "give" as the diameter is slightly large than the spool hole, causing an interference fit. This will be a very snug fit.

Quick assembly and usage demo

This is a very simple design inspired by a baby bottle drying rack. I originally created this a couple years ago but didn't bother to upload it then. I recently made a small tweak and decided to share it. Of course, now there are several other Sinus Rinse drying racks on Thingiverse (like thing:623194) that are superior to this, so you'll probably want one of those instead.

I am currently the proud owner of a newborn Reprap Prusa Printer.  
I still have some way to go in getting my RepRap performing at it's peak.  What I have learned so far is that cooling your printer is important.  As well as keeping the thermal barrier cool in the hot end of the printer, the other area of the printer that gets nice and toasty is the electronics.  
I tried to passively cool my StepStick stepper motor drivers with some heatsinks, but after a long session printing they were pretty hot.  So I designed this.
The Ramps Cooler/Guard is a pretty simple design as you can see, but it is effective and pretty neat.
I also felt that it would be useful to me to gain a little feedback from my printer so I have added three holes to the right hand side of the piece to furnish two red LEDs and a green LED.  These quite simply are connected to the power input, heat-bed heater and extruder tip outputs on the RAMPS board.  The green LED tells me that there is 12v power to the the printer, the red LEDs come on when my heaters are active.
The mounting holes for a RAMPS shield match of course the Arduino Mega, so there may be other applications for this design.  In a future version I may add a power switch, but feel free to add one if you use my design.
IMPORTANT.  The mounting holes will need adjusting in the .scad file for your printer/hardware.

• Download the OpenScad File

  • Open it in OpenScad and adjust the hole sizes to match your printer and mounting screws.

  • Print

  • Attach a 50mm fan

  • Solder resistors to one of the legs of your LEDs and add wire to the other leg.

  • Attach the LEDs to the Ramps Cooler/Guard. you can push fit them in place if your holes are the right dimensions. A small spot of glue might be necessary.

  • Attach the LED's and fan's wires to the relevant screw terminals of the RAMPS shield.

  • Cross your fingers and fire up your printer.

description.text: This is the Milnor fiber of the simple cusp singularity. Notice that the boundary is a trefoil knot.

The pipeline is the following:  
Sage, to compute the equations (you need to compose the stereographic projection with the function that defines the singularity, and then separate real and imaginary parts).  
Then use meshlab to generate the meshes.  
Finally, use blender to thicken the mesh and cut the part that correspond to the oppsite fiber.

This is a rough draft of the framework necessary for an axial flux generator, a type of non-commutated turbine ideal for home construction. Great for wind turbines!

I don't recommend you try to make this thing yet! I'm still saving up for a RepRap, so I don't know how well it works, if at all. I'll post more instructions as I progress with the project, but the basic idea is: 1) rotor (you'll need two copies)
a) print the main component (rotor.scad or rotor.stl)
b) print rotor_cap
c) rotor_magnet_cap needs to be made of steel to correctly shape the flux; there are companies that do 3D printing of metal, or you can find an appropriately sized hubcap. I'm planning to order copies made of steel after trimming it down a bit.
b) place magnets in the rotor such that they have the same polarity relative to the center axis (i.e. each magnet should repel the magnets next to it). BE EXTREMELY CAREFUL IF YOU ARE USING RARE EARTH MAGNETS; you can easily lose a finger or worse if one magnet attracts another.
c) screw on the rotor_cap and rotor_magnet_cap as demonstrated in turbine.scad 2) stator
a) print the stator
b) place wire coils (I still need to design a winder for these) in the holes and secure with epoxy or similar; make certain you've configured them correctly before securing them permanently (I plan to use a 3-phase configuration, details to come). 3) place the stator on top of the bottom rotor
4) place a lazy susan bearing on top of the stator
5) secure the top rotor on the assembly â€” USE EXTREME CAUTION! If you are using rare earth magnets, the attractive force will be measurable in tons!
6) you're done with the generator! Now you need to attach it to a resistor, and something that turns...

The Pythagorean cup is a drinking vessel designed to drain its contents via siphon action if it is overfilled. If the cup is partially filled, it holds liquid which can be drunk in the usual fashion. If it is overfilled it drains the entire contents of the cup into the drinker's lap. This object was classically used as a warning of the dangers of gluttony and over-consumption. Unfortunately, Pythagorean cups feature a distinctive central stem to house the siphon tube which drains the cup - see for instance http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27533. This gives away the surprise and spoils some of the fun! Fortunately, modern 3D printing allows us to build a more devious cup, with a hidden siphon. This object is a Pythagorean cup with the siphon tube concealed in the drinking vessel walls. The siphon tube traverses more than 300 degrees of the circumference of the rim, so a moderately filled cup will not drain when it is tilted. This object has been printed and tested, and is 100% functional! It makes a great brainteaser or science demonstration for students.

This object was originally printed on a Makerbot Replicator 2: Material: Makerbot True Yellow PLA
Layer Thickness: 0.2 mm
Shells: 3
Temp: 240 C
Infill Type: Hex
Infill Density: 20%
Raft: None
Supports: None All other settings remained at the Makerware "standard" profile default values. The cup should be oriented in a standing fashion for printing. For other printers and materials, the chief concern is producing a watertight or nearly watertight surface on the inside of the cup and siphon tube. If you have trouble achieving this, decrease the layer thickness to 0.1mm and bump up the number of shells. If this does not do the trick, tune your extruder for fatter extrusions. The STL file produces a ~8 cm tall cup at native scale. The STL mesh is dense enough that it should scale up or down very nicely. I have included the original Solidworks file used to produce the STL in case anyone would like to improve this design. If another file format is requested, please leave a comment.

comments.text: The problem with not having the central column is that if the drinker does not know how the cup is designed, they most certainly will spill all their drink. If the user brings the cup to the mouth with the internal pipe closest, the cup will empty. The reason for the central column is that when the cup is brought to the mouth the water level will not rise above the top of the internal pipe. The designer of the first cup probably had the tools to build the pipe in the walls of the cup but choose not to.  I designed my own column-less cup not thinking about this and learnt this the hard way.

description.text: I thought it would be pretty cool to roll up a message (like an old scroll) and wax seal it.  So I designed a wax stamp imprinted with "K P" (my initial, and my wife's initial) in FreeCAD.  That got me thinking... perhaps the Thingiverse community would also like to 3D print stamps!  Well, here's a customizer just for you!

The YouTube video outlines the process. But in words you: (1) melt the wax, (2) distribute the wax, (3) let the wax cool for 30-40 seconds, (4) firmly push and hold the stamp into the wax for 60 seconds, and (5) carefully pry the stamp away from the wax. Video: https://youtu.be/W0y92Z9LlZA

Printer:

BraggBot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

<= 0.3

Infill:

= 33%

Notes: I used ABS for this stamp (because putting the stamp in hot wax will surely raise it's temperature). Also, the high infill value is to facilitate heat dissipation and rigidity when pulling the stamp away from the wax.

I finally decided to make some proper stands for the portion of my phaser collection that don't have their own already*. Mostly this means customized or stock Art Asylum (aka Diamond Select) phasers, but also a Playmates model and a B&W I built from a 23rd Century Pistol kit. I used one of JamesH's ST symbols (68426) and then added an angled coupling for the phaser handle. These are canted at 10 degrees. This makes them almost level when displayed, but still retains a bit of that rakish slant. There are three stands, so choose accordingly. :)
    • Fortuitously, the handle of an AA phaser will fit snugly in one of those white Apple headphone cases. I had access to a few, so that's what I've been using for some of them.

This is a rough draft of a Darrieus/Savonius combination vertical-axis wind turbine intended for use with an axial flux generator.

I don't recommend you try to make this thing yet! I'm still saving up for a RepRap, so I don't know how well it works, if at all. I'll post more instructions as I progress with the project, but the basic idea is: 1) assemble an axial flux generator as described on the page for that Thing
2) print 8 rotor_arms
3) print 1 rotor_airfoil_tie
4) secure 4 rotor_arms to the bottom rotor of the generator
5) secure the other 4 rotor_arms together with the rotor_airfoil_tie
6) cut a sheet of plastic into 4 airfoils of your desired size (I'm planning on 3' tall)
7) secure each airfoil between two rotor_arms with superglue You should have a functional wind turbine!

https://youtu.be/LGFUjzvBPuI

Coming soon!! The main aims of the V2 remix were to: Support standard 9g servos [previously I was using Tower Pro SG90 servos]
Make everything easier to assemble [no more need for glue]
Make it easier to adapt/modify for other phones. The new bracket system made it easier to exchange a new phone / the battery holder. Also, in my V2 Remix build, I'm also using the Arduino Nano instead of the DIY Nano shield, so the entire build is smaller and tidier. :) MobBob V2 Remix uses the same software as the original MobBob V2. You can find the latest Arduino code here: https://github.com/cevinius/MobBob
The modified code is included: MobBob2_Remix_Control_Bluetooth.ino You can download the latest version of the Android app from Google Play - it is free, ad-free, and without IAP:
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.cevinius.MobBob You can find more detailed build and wiring instructions here:
...coming soon... The parts that you need to print: 1 x Leg Left
1 x Leg Right
1 x Foot Left....................................Delete

1 x Foot Cover Right........................Delete

1 x Cap The non-3D printed parts you need are: 4 x Tower Pro SG90 servos
1 x Arduino Nano ATmega328 [see note below]
1 x HM-10 BLE Bluetooth 4.0 CC2540 CC2541 Serial Wireless Module
1 x 5V Micro USB 1A Lithium Battery Charging Board [see note below]
1 x DC-DC Converter Step Up Boost Module 2-5V to 5V 1.2A
1 x Rectangle On/Off Long Rocker Switch SPST
2 x Snap-In Single 'A'-'AA' Battery Contacts 209 [KEYSTONE ELECTRONICS CORP.]

2 x 18650 Lithium ion Batteries
1 x 300mm USB 2.0 A Male to Micro USB B 5pin + Mini B Male Y Splitter Cable
1 x Smart Phone [see note below]
4 x M3 5mm [for Foot Cover]
2 x M2 10mm [for Phone Connect]
4 x M2 5mm [for Phone Mount Back Plate]
2 x 2mm 5mm Tapping screw [for Foot servos]
2 x 2mm 8mm Tapping screw [for Hip servos]

2 x M3 15mm [for Jacket]
2 x M3 Nut [for Jacket]
4 x 2mm 15mm Tapping screw [for Jacket]
[Note: I got the servos, Arduino Nano, Bluetooth Module and Battery for under $30.] Arduino Nano: This is a small, Arduino compatible ATmega328 board with DIY extension board. MobBob V2 app connects to the Bluetooth module using its Bluetooth LE service. The app to support other Bluetooth cards. Battery Extender: You can use other batteries that provide 5V with a steady current. If you use other batteries, you may need to adapt the battery rack for your battery's size.
Use 18650 Lithium Battery Charging Board With Protection Charger Module and Step Up Boost Module 3.7V to 5V for Smart Phone
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1235749 Smart Phone: You can use other Android Smart Phones with This app.
You do not need to adapt the size of the phone holder for your phone. The app has been successfully tested with Nexus and Samsung, LG phones, but should work on other Android phones. Instructions: Print all the required parts
Get all the non-3D printed parts
Assemble as per the photos - I'll be writing some more detailed instructions on my website soon!
Install the Arduino code from the GitHub link in the description - You will need to update the Arduino pins in the code to match yours, and probably update the centering values for the servos.
Install the Android app from the link in the description. Have fun! If you hit any problems, please post a question on this website: [http://www.cevinius.com], here, or on YouTube channel. A few people have built MobBobs now, so there are people around who can help. Coming soon update!!

description.text:
This is a more complicated box for Gwent cards from Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt. It is my own personal design I made with Solidworks. It has a belt loop for carrying your cards and the small tabs at the bottom are for keeping the card holder in place. Newly improved design includes a loop for tying the box closed with a leather strap during long rides.
It comes in two pieces, the inner piece holds the long Gwent cards of the style that come in the special edition expansion pack, The Hearts of Stone box from Gamestop. It has a small handle tab on the bottom to allow for easy removal. The outer cover then slides over it to protect them. It should hold one of the factions from that set. 
It now has the cover designs from each of the Gwent factions available thanks to Slugshot providing me his faction designs. The side walls are 1/8 inch thick and I printed mine in ABS plastic, thus made it can withstand blows from a normal hammer and show little to no damage. I have included the plain box so you can customize it with your own Gwent faction symbols for custom decks.
The cover picture shows the originally designed Gwent box without the improved holding rings. Also pictured is the Gwent deck it was designed to house (Monster faction) and one of the little toy fashion scoring rubies from a dollar store pack. Which you can download a 3D model for among my other Gwent models.

title: Cover lid for A-collection towel dryer thermostat.

description.text:
This is an extension cover for a a-collection towel dryer thermostat.
(From the Nordic Group Ahlsell.)
I have a towel dryer from Hafa with both thermostatic mixer (water) and electric heater with thermostat from A-collection.
The combination set the towel dryer about 15mm further away from the wall.
There are extenders included for the wall brackets and the mixer but the cover for the electrical connection does not bridge the longer gap.
I made this to solve the issue.
The lid is fixed with two M2x10 screws although they are not really necessary as the parts lock eachother.
Printed in chroma green ABS. Later painted black.
The black original sliding cover can be seen in the pictures.

description.text:

I figured it would be a good way to save $5 on a new one, even if I might have to replace it every once in a while...
Also note that I based this design on the custom machined pin (don't know what happened to the stock ones) that came off my car. My doorstop holes have been drilled out and are bigger than they should be, so please tell me if it doesn't fit!
Not sure if many fellow thing owners own 3d printers... Make sure to leave a comment if you do!

author: kolt

description.text:
Another lm6uu replacement carriage for the badly designed techzone x axis.
This one is narrow to keep 140+ mm of travel
It use only two LM6UU so make sure the zip tie are secured ! To use it you need to replace the imperial rods by 6mm rods and buy 2 LM6UU of course.
(it's up to you to replace the imperial by the 6mm, you may need to print new huxely part with 6mm hole instead of 6.35mm) Don't forget to put a fan on it otherwise it will melt from the nozzle's heat(especially with PLA) The pro are :
  • identical mounting hole for nozzle as the original
  • smoother movement against the "impossible to get aligned brass tube"
  • better precision than "never correctly tighten bearings"
  • simpler design
  • fan mounting option
  • asymmetrical design
    • The cons :
  • only two lm6uu
  • need a fan not taller than nozzle
  • fan stream not optimized around nozzle.
  • asymmetrical design
    • Be aware that you can print it in mirror like me to change the side of the belt clamp or put nozzle more left / right.

Printer:

Huxley techzone

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

80%

A 3D printable HP-41 battery replacement. You can stick in 4 sub AAA NiMH cells or go for the pro version, which powers a HP-41 from either
  • 2 AAA NiMH cells or
  • 1 old Li-Ion mobile phone battery, USB chargeable
    • http://www.askrprojects.net/hardware/hp41bat/index.html

WARNING: In case you decide to use the Li-Ion version: I intentionally wrote and mean "old Li-Ion phone battery" and nothing else! These types of Li-Ion batteries come with an integrated short-circuit as well as undervoltage protection! === I prepared three battery cases:
  • a standard, two part version
  • a single part, open top version
  • a single part, open top version with charger hole
    • The open top version comes in handy for NiMH operation, whereas the closed, two part version was developed for old phone batteries. All parts are already in their printing position.
    Please notice that the the single part case, as well as the bottom part of the standard, two part version require support structures for an overhanging edge and the two snap-in detents. For a (little more complete) description, just follow the the link above.

title: Y-Z-axes fixation for Geeetech i3 X

description.text:
Z-Axis stabilizer. Improves the overall rigidness of the printer. However, it is not necessary, except if you like to transport the printer. Initially this thing was meant to remove the twist of the Y-X-plane. However, it turned out to tilt the Z-axis instead of the Y-axis if the printer was twisted because the Y-axis is much more rigid. This fixation does not help alone - another fixation will be necessary...
  • Version 1 is tight and is made with no clearance. Requires careful support removal.
  • Version 2 has +0.4mm clearance.
    • Similar construction as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:921948. You'll need two M8 threaded rods with a length of 45cm each (buy 1m and cut it with a Dremel), 8 M8 nuts and 8 washers. The upper part is fixed to the smooth z-rod by a m3 nut and a m3 screw. [Unstable server connection. Had to retype the text again.]

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Geeetech i3 X

Notes: You must use support and brim is recommended. Use also "support bridges" to get smooth inner faces. More infill than regular is also recommended. I used 20%. The bottom part will be ugly, so I suggest to print it with visible sides facing upward. Removing the supports will be a time consuming task. I used the small sturdy blade of a swiss army knife, a flat wide screwdriver and small pliers. Cut off the support at the 2 interface layers and the walls, rip it out with the pliers and screwdriver and remove the remaining support with the knife.
I did not use rotable rod fixation (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:921948) to keep design simple. However, in such a way this design only fits the mentioned stock printer.

comments.text: did you print the parts with your geeetech without thos fixation ?
comments.author: 3D_CC_design

comments.text: Yes. I printed stuff without this fixation. I have manually bent the Y-X-plane to remove the twist: Using 3 leveling screws only (remove the fourth screw and spring) the Y-X-plane should be perfectly adjustable. If not, then there is a twist of the Y-X-plane. So I bent the plane until the 4th (not adjustable) corner of the Y-X-plane had the right distance to the nozzle. In such a way I also mounted the fixation. However, this fixation is not enough as written in the description.
comments.author: 3D_CC_design

title: Star Wars LPA NN-14 Rey's Blaster Pistol w/ Compartment for Electronics

description.text:
This is my model of the blaster that Han Solo gives Rey in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. As soon as I saw this blaster I knew I needed it so I immediately learned blender and made it. This is my first model I've made from scratch so constructive criticism is welcome! The screws are missing because I have real Torx Security panhead screws I wanted to use. If you want to print them I'm sure you can just superglue them to the holes to cover them up. I even left a compartment and a hole in the barrel for if you want to put an LED in it! Thanks to Bowie for experimenting. You need: "for the body we used 24 pcs of M3 - .50 x 6
for the grip we used 4 pcs of M4 - .70 x 10"
plus 4 random hard drive screws because they are tiny or you can print the heads and glue them on NOTE: You cannot take my design and sell it on eBay without my consent, message me first and then we can talk EDIT: 1/2/2016: I updated the files so that they are the right dimensions and proper orientation on the bed

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes: Only the Top Power Cell Portion needs supports
Blender First time Blender user

comments.text:
I just printed it but used inches by scaling up times 25.4.
Did as a project with my grandson (11 yrs.). Had the Form1+, Form 2, (50u resolution) and Make-it Pro (100u) all going at the same time through the night so pieces would be ready when he came over. Greggo did a great job and things line up well. I bought 3 and 4 mm metric screws and a tap, but the resin (the thick parts) wasn't as consistent to tap as I expected. I printed the grips in Vortex Amber resin, and he lightly painted some Red Oak stain over only the out-facing side; they are very realistic. He is happy. Greggo left room inside to put batteries and a laser controller, so we can do that on another visit. Most is painted nickel flake, and I got some black MinWax 'stain' that we will use to antique it a little more. It is not a show piece, but a fun project to do together.

description.text:
This is my first attempt at a replica Air Arms .177 Magazine.
OK I have printed one and it needs a little bit of work. I am waiting for a digital caliper to arrive so that I can make accurate measurements. It isn't far out but not good enough to cycle itself in use. You can use manually rotating (like an aftermarket for S400) but would like to reproduce a properly working replica. I think that it will be strong enough for the task once I get the build correct. Look forward to version 1-2. OK V1-2 files are here. To be honest check out my V2 external 'O' ring magazine it is better design for cleaning supports and works great.

description.text:
[Version 1.0]
This print is your simple solution to keep birds from leaving behind little goodies on your mailbox every morning! These low-profile bird spikes simply snap on to Imperial Mailbox number plates with ease. Print/paint black to best match your mailbox. Try one out today, as it's a very quick print (about 35-45 min)!
Comments and Suggestions welcome!

Best result with my Flashforge Creator (Replicator Dual) was made with these settings:
-Raft
-Full Support
-100% Infill
-0.27mm Layer Height
-1 Shell
-Default Replicator Feed Rates and Temperatures If your printer doesn't like "Clip_Final", try "Clip V3" instead

title: Dash Cam Mount for FHD 1080P and alike
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Final update: I had to redesign the arm and the holder due to the odd shaped mirror arm (it slipped out). The v2 parts fit perfectly and are very very stable. You do not need to remove the mirror to fit it. This is a holder for the Chinese FHD 1080P Car Cam Corder (dash cam) and alike.
I wanted a holder which attaches to the reverse view mirror arm so it can hide the camera.
The mount also features a ball design so it can be adjusted easily.
It is designed for a Passat 2006 B6 model but should be able to work on other models, i have included the original drawing files if you want to make modifications to it. Please note:
  • For a better fit the nut needs to be scaled up by 1% the stl file already has that but not the drawing files.
  • The arm is designed 2 mm shorter on purpose so when attached to the camera it will pull from the side (hence why it looks skew on the picture) i wanted to be more secure as it can get quite bumpy on some roads and i don't trust the Chinese hold mount (it does fit very snugly so it should be ok, just me being paranoid).
    • Parts Required:
    1 x Hex Socket Cap m3 x 28mm
    1 x M3 nut As usual i have included the 123dx file and a step(.stp) export.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

40%

Notes: note that you don't need supports for the nut but are required for the other two. V2 parts do not need supports.

description.text:
Started a school project, where my students have to design their own phone stands.
It's still a work in progress and more designs will follow. They sometimes use designs from other people here on thingieverse, wich they adept, use and/or redesign. So please don't get angry if you see a design of ours being used. It's a school project, they are learning.

comments.text: My guess is that you're using a DaVinci 1.0 printer.  That print is exhibiting several of the classic issues with that printer that can easily be fixed by stabilizing the print bed.  1) The glass is not firmly attached to the build platform and can slide around and 2) the lower right rear bushing is loose in the black plastic fitting.  It needs to be secured.  Once you do both of those, recalibrate the print bed height and you should get dramatically improved prints out of it.
